oai_dc:dc.dc:title: St. Luke African Methodist Episcopal Church: front facade
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: St. Luke African Methodist Episcopal Church
2803 21st Ave. N., Birmingham, Jefferson County, AL

Color photograph of the front of a buff-colored brick one-story church. The facade features three symmetrical bays with a tiny parapet crest in the center over a louvered vent. It has a one-story plain portico with pediment, which is supported by wrought iron poles. Three nearly square wood windows of stained glass are symmetrically arranged on the balcony level. On the main level there are two rectangular stained glass windowsto each side of two double six-panel wood doors. Two levels of stone and concrete steps lead from the front sidewalk and from both sides to the sanctuary entrance. In the middle of the staircase is a metal railing. On the first level of the stairs are two large wrought iron poles, which once held exterior lamps.

St. Luke AME church, designed by Wallace Rayfield and built in 1926, was one of the leading Birmingham churches involved in the Alabama Christian Movement for Human Rights (ACMHR) during the key years for civil rights actions in Birmingham. Rev. Andrew W. Thomas, pastor from 1956-1969, was an early activist with ACMHR and opened his church to many of the mass meetings of that group. Among notable speakers at the church were Reverends Fred Shuttlesworth, Edward Gardner, James Bevel, Martin Luther King and Ralph Abernathy. The church was an important strategy center for planning of Project C in 1963, a campaign of nonviolent confrontational actions, such as lunch room sit-ins.
